The words came out flat, the punchline thudding between us like a stone skipping only once before sinking.I used to laugh easily, loud and sudden, the way sunlight slips through curtains in the morning. Now, laughter feels like a language I once spoke fluently but have forgotten. My friends nudge me at school, share memes and silly stories, and I try—I really try—to join in. But the ache sits at my throat, a stone I carry and can’t seem to set down.One night, my brother crawls into my bed and whispers, “Tell me the joke again.” I close my eyes and breathe. His hand finds mine, small and warm. I start, voice trembling, but this time, he giggles before I even reach the end. And somehow, for a moment, I remember what laughter feels like.
